channel.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @ExtremeX-Scape Ryley
item.description:
@ExtremeX-Scape wrote:

[quote=“zyle1992, post:22, topic:464976”]Pretty good, just a few things that I figured I’d add.

  1. I usually don’t specify the implementation on the left side unless I know that it won’t be changed. Take the following code
final ArrayList<String> names = new ArrayList<String>();

If an ArrayList is the suitable implementation of the List interface that I need, and I either a) know that the implementation should never change or b) not allow an outside source (end-user) to change the implementation, than why should it matter?

  1. For things like a group of players, where each is unique, than a Set would be a more suitable solution, as it does not allow duplicate entries.[/quote]

LinkedHashSet would be the better choice here.

LinkedHashSet has good performance, doesn’t allow duplicate entries, and has predictable iteration order, iterating in the order that the elements were inserted into the Set.

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @zyle1992 Zymus
item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Pretty good, just a few things that I figured I’d add.

  1. I usually don’t specify the implementation on the left side unless I know that it won’t be changed. Take the following code
final ArrayList<String> names = new ArrayList<String>();

If an ArrayList is the suitable implementation of the List interface that I need, and I either a) know that the implementation should never change or b) not allow an outside source (end-user) to change the implementation, than why should it matter?

  1. For things like a group of players, where each is unique, than a Set would be a more suitable solution, as it does not allow duplicate entries.

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Unless you need to utilize methods specific to arraylist always declare your collection as:

List<Blah> objects = new ArrayList<Blah>();

Speaking of I have never been a fan of array list. And I think this has been touched up on.

@Davidi2: The unique identifier for players should be their encoded username. IF you were to have a login server then I would say a global identifier would be useful. But honestly I think both are one in the same.

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

In the case of the lottery, you’d still be better of using object oriented programming by having something like an ArrayList, and the ticket object has the players username and ticket information. But even then, I still think something like a unique player ID is better than a display name, they use less memory and are easier to store. Unfortunately most servers dont have these unless they use some sort of SQL player saving or have a smart developer. I’m still pretty sure barbarian assault ends the wave if you log out though…

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

The situation I am describing is in runescape. Barbarian Assault is an example that I can think of. If a player logs out and they log back in (while their team is still on the same level) the game continues. I believe if the players try finishing the level, they are unable to do so until the player logs back in. The reason they had this setup was because if someone randomly dced the game could continue.

Also, I found a src that uses the approach I had in mind. https://www.assembla.com/code/darkquest/subversion/nodes/DarkQuest/src/org/darkquest/gs/plugins/minigames/Lottery.java?rev=80

The tutorial is aimed more towards how Java, specifically an ArrayList can be used in a rsps. Someone starting from scratch and is new to game developing in general, should learn the useful tools the java api has to offer.

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @relexlawl relexlawl
item.description:
@relexlawl wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:4, topic:464976”][quote author=relexlawl link=topic=569200.msg4129797#msg4129797 date=1350937847]
Conventions state that the less specific object goes on the left, not really sure how to explain, but basically you would do

List mgBlue = new ArrayList();

instead of

ArrayList mgBlue = new ArrayList();

Same with maps, etc

Also should start teaching people how to take a more OO approach to coding, i.e in this example you want to add and remove players, so should just store it as a player

List mgBlue = new ArrayList();
[/quote]

With the first concern, I always have it in my head to do
ArrayList mgBlue = new ArrayList();
does it really matter? If I make it List, I have to import it as well…

For the second concern, I completely forgot about it 

private ArrayList<Player> players = new ArrayList<Player>();

To take this approach, you are still going to want an ArrayList to check player names (if they log out/in)

.add§;
.add(p.getUsername());

If players logout, they shouldn’t be grabbed from the minigame. If they login, they should be reconsidered.
This tutorial is aimed to be basic and an intro. I could write something up, more for private servers if need-be.[/quote]

Quote from graham:

Btw it is good practice to use the least specific type on the left side of a declaration - e.g. here:

1
private static HashMap<Class<? extends RSProtocol>, RSClientFactory> factories = new HashMap<Class<? extends RSProtocol>, RSClientFactory>();
you would change it to this:

1
private static Map<Class<? extends RSProtocol>, RSClientFactory> factories = new HashMap<Class<? extends RSProtocol>, RSClientFactory>();
This makes it easier if you ever want to change the actual implementation, as all the other code referring to this variable, copying it, etc. will be using thta least-specific Map type - you only have to change HashMap to e.g. TreeMap in one place, rather than everywhere you use it.

For the second thing, I don’t know of ANY minigame where that needs to occur (including barbarian assault), anyway removing the name or the player is the same thing, just one if more OO and you won’t need to loop through every player when trying to match the name to one of the players online.

Read full topic

item.title: ArrayList - Utilizing in a server
item.dc:creator: @Rodgerwilco Rodgerwilco
item.description:
@Rodgerwilco wrote:

JDK 6 - http://docs.oracle.com/javase/6/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html
JDK 7 - http://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/util/ArrayList.html

I will be using JDK 6 for this tutorial. One of the first things I learned about Java was utilizing arrays for a bot I fooled around with back in 2007-08ish. If you are new to Java, specifically ArrayList, this tutorial is for you.

So first thing is first, why would we use an ArrayList in a rsps? Well we can use an ArrayList to add players to a specific minigame or possibly a clan chat system is the first thing that comes to mind. For the sake of the tutorial I will be doing a custom minigame.

To start, we need to create the ArrayList by importing java.util.ArrayList. We will use a “String” data type as we will be using player names.

import java.util.ArrayList;

//two different teams :)
//forget the static, read up on it later.
	public static ArrayList<String> mgBlue = new ArrayList<String>();
	public static ArrayList<String> mgRed = new ArrayList<String>();

The ArrayList is created, now we want to add/remove players to the ArrayList. I provided the links to the api so you guys can read up on the methods provided. In a private server, you are going to want an npc or game object/item whatever to add the player to the ArrayList. Minigames and games in general are just an illusion to the player but yet simple tasks in the backend of the game.

In the scenario that players join our mini game, Let’s add players to both teams.

add(E e) Appends the specified element to the end of this list.
		mgBlue.add("Rodgerwilco");
		mgRed.add("Dds2hit");

For testing purposes, lets see how many players are on each team. Again, in a rsps we would want the world to tell everyone how many are on each team, or maybe specific players. Since we are not working with a game source and we are working with the basics I will use System.out.println();

		System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
		System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());

It should spit out one on each team

Now since we have players being added to our array, we need a way to remove them, if they leave the area they obviously are not playing, so you we will use the remove method.

remove(Object o) Removes the first occurrence of the specified element from this list, if it is present.

		mgBlue.remove("Rodgerwilco");

And for the sake of testing, let’s spit out the amount on each team.

System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size()); System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());

If you are starting from scratch, your code should look something like this.

[code]import java.util.ArrayList;

public class ArrayTut {

public static ArrayList<String> mgBlue = new ArrayList<String>();
public static ArrayList<String> mgRed = new ArrayList<String>();


/**
 * @param args
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {
	
	mgBlue.add("Rodgerwilco");
	mgRed.add("Dds2hit");
	System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
	System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());
	
	mgBlue.remove("Rodgerwilco");
	
	System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
	System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());

}

}
[/code]

And your output :

Amt of players on blue team : 1 Amt of players on red team : 1 Amt of players on blue team : 0 Amt of players on red team : 1

Now let’s progress. We have a way to add and remove players, but what if the minigame ends? We don’t want these players in the teams arraylist anymore… so let’s remove them.

clear() Removes all of the elements from this list.
                mgRed.clear();
		System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());

Awesome, now we can clear the minigame arrays when we feel like it/when the minigame is over. What if a minigame is getting crowded? Let’s say we only want 3 people on each team… I created a new method for this and I will walk you through it.

We can check the size of an array by using the size() method.

int size() Returns the number of elements in this list.

private static void addPlayerToBlueMG(String s) { if(mgBlue.size() < 3) { mgBlue.add(s); } else { System.out.println("srry"); } }

A simple size check, if the size > 3… sorry… else add the player. Simple eh?

We learned how to :
Add a player to an arraylist.
Remove a player.
Clear all players.
Check for the size.

Those are pretty much the basics and should get you started, have any questions… feel free to ask.

[code]import java.util.ArrayList;

public class ArrayTut {

public static ArrayList<String> mgBlue = new ArrayList<String>();
public static ArrayList<String> mgRed = new ArrayList<String>();

/**
 * @param args
 */
public static void main(String[] args) {
	
	
	mgBlue.add("Rodgerwilco");
	mgRed.add("Dds2hit");
	System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
	System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());
	
	mgBlue.remove("Rodgerwilco");
	
	System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
	System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());
	
	mgRed.clear();

	System.out.println("Amt of players on red team : " + mgRed.size());
	
	addPlayerToBlueMG("Hey");
	addPlayerToBlueMG("How");
	addPlayerToBlueMG("Are");
	addPlayerToBlueMG("You");
	
	System.out.println("Amt of players on blue team : " + mgBlue.size());
	
	
}

private static void addPlayerToBlueMG(String s) {
	if(mgBlue.size() < 3) {
		mgBlue.add(s);
	} else {
		System.out.println("srry");
	}
}

}
[/code]

Read full topic
